lessonOverview.title: Unit 1 - Lesson 2
structures: A: What do you do at the beach?
A: What does he/she do at the beach?

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six beach activities (make sandcastles, play Frisbee, eat ice cream, collect shells, explore rock pools, have a picnic) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Mime beach activities (e.g., making a sandcastle). Students guess and name the activity. Then write it in their notebooks.
stretchStrategies: Students role-play “A Day at the Beach,” sequencing 3 activities they and a friend do, then present it to another pair.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about beach activities using “What do you do at the beach?” / “What does he/she do at the beach?” and respond with “I...” / “He/She...”.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Pair Q&A: “What do you do at the beach?” / “I collect shells.” Swap partners after 2 questions.
stretchStrategies: Students role-play “A Day at the Beach,” sequencing 3 activities they and a friend do, then present it to another pair.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “What do you do at the beach?” / “What does he/she do at the beach?” / “I ___.” / “He/She ___.” to talk about beach activities.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Board drill: teacher gives a prompt card (e.g., “he / play Frisbee”), students form and say: “He plays Frisbee.”
stretchStrategies: Students role-play “A Day at the Beach,” sequencing 3 activities they and a friend do, then present it to another pair.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)
A wide variety of syllabus hobbies may be less popular or available to some Vietnamese students (practising the flute; seeing famous paintings), although many overlap
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Certain common holiday activities are less likely to overlap with those of Western kids (eating seafood at the beach, going on tours in large groups)
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
